8IVVrVMVYDpgcoDM5votuA.text: I like Filipino food. This place has a great selection of meals, snacks, and desserts. Yummy stuff.

G0ZeE5DX37lWFh1o-w5Cdg.text: Mind-blowingly good. The chicken dishes literally brought back childhood memories. Portions are appropriate and desserts were fantastic. Owners were especially nice.

TVoS8AkCIpHzpYSiGevisA.text: I went to Casa Filipina Bakeshop & Restaurant. I am no expert on Filipino food. I have only been to one in CA twice. I  want to find a place in Phoenix. Surprise there is one 7 miles from where I live.  They are located in a strip mall. You may miss them unless you was looking. Very simple lay out. Has a home feeling. Nothing fancy. Clean. As you enter you pass a glass case with very good looking pastries. An extremely nice young man showed me to a table. It was about 4:30pm so I was the only person in the restaurant. He asked if I had eaten Filipino food before. I told him only twice before and I would need help. He suggested the beef steak. Prepared in a sauce with onion and potatoes. No processed taste, genuine home cooked meal.  Very taste. There was a salad of fine noodles. I did enjoy everything I had a dessert of Ube and a cup of coffee. When i left everyone invited me back. It was only about 5:15pm by now and they were setting up for a band that plays there on Fridays. I have been to a lot of places to eat. The people here made me feel at home and welcome. I am going back. Probably tomorrow for lunch or dinner. I gave them 4 stars. I will probably change this to a 5 next review.

eLm2rAzcivUXYJq-x53zwg.text: Great little family owned restaurant.  The lumpias and chicken inasal were yummy and fresh. I will definitely go back to get my Filipino food fix.

TNM0mX3EjV-JOqvbGm2oZw.text: We enjoyed several plates here.  By far my favorite was the pork belly of course.  I love bacon so pork belly is a must.  The pork belly came out cut up in perfect two bite morsels for me.  A nice crunchy top with a soft underside is a great mix of meat goodness.  The sauce is on the sweet side, but not so much that it takes away flavor.  Plus it is a great sweet sauce for the meat. We also had the Pan cit Malabon, which has a spaghetti type noodle that is cut up.  I mean the texture and thickness reminded me of a spaghetti noodle.  The shrimp was only ok, as noted by a dinner guest on mine.  I cannot comment as I am allergic to shellfish.  I did chance the noodles since the top is sprinkled with pork rinds.  Interesting, but not my first pick next visit. The fired chicken was good, very crispy, but for the $7.99 price 2 pieces of chicken was not what I expected.  With everything else on the larger side I found this to be lacking in value for my dollar. We also sampled the flan dessert, which was creamy and sweet.  Nice mix and most likely I would try again.  I also tried the Halo-halo which my first experience.  Nice dessert that I would go for again.  A mix of sweet, ice and a small slice of flan on top.  All enjoyed in a plastic cup for you to enjoy for at least a half an hour of mixing ice with the sweet bottom mix.    If you are in the area and craving a great Filipino food experience stop here.  I will try some other dishes next time I am in the area.

UBrdIGNUSPAvD6UyqqVyeg.text: This restaurant is by far one of the best around. Great authentic Philipino food! Everything is wonderful!

FlX_gCI6Uu2lwKgLdU1aYg.text: Cool live music at the restaurant that was quite good. The menu is very old and needs to be updated to describe True prices of desserts and the real timing of karaoke night (Saturday). Good dinner food. Pancit and puto were my favorite. The mousse tower was really good, the ube torte was blah but the cannoli is where everything went downhill. It was absolutely disgusting, possibly overstaying it's welcome, sour, and the worst cannoli I have ever tried.

wDX8TLlpYgEnGudNiKFHRg.text: Started a yelp account just to complain about this place...Bought my grandma an order of kare kare and I was so disappointed...   since it was  a to-go order they asked me what size i wanted and i told them the medium size cup. it was $8 but since I figured the container was pretty big, it would be worth it. When we got our food, it was in a different container and we didn't open it til we got home. There were 2 small pieces of meat with a little bit of sauce. This measly portion could have fit in the small to-go container that was $3 cheaper.   We called the restaurant to complain about the small serving size we got and the lady on the phone ask two asked us things that turned me from irritated and a little upset to angry and outraged. First she asked it we were regulars then if I was Filipino.  Hmmm..I didn't know that their level of customer service was based on restaurant loyalty and nationality.  So what if I'm not a regular customer or Filipino? doesnt that mean they can give me smaller portions for the same price? I'll never eat at this place again!!

RlYlomiqYoerRFgFmAIQJA.text: Good service, Decent food, Delicious Deserts! Would definitely recommend the Tiramisu or Lechon!

UjNBkTz7zDQLGk6WMYDrTg.text: Hands down the best Filipino restaurant in Phoenix, probably in Arizona. The staff went above & beyond catering to my mom and aunt (who's natives of Sebu) ensuring they feel right at home. Food was authentic and the atmosphere is inviting. Tess is the greatest Filipino pastry chef (even though she didn't have any Pandesol) ! Live music with singing and dancing ensures you'll definitely come back.

rccZVgIO1265Sl1QLXWzbg.text: Anytime I each Filipino food outside of my own or family's own kitchen, I'm always nervous about what surprise im in for. In this case, it was a good treat. Being in an area away from home, I wanted something close to home cooking. The food was good (not the best, but not horrible).   I would come here again

vmjDBia__dVR-AVRenLWgA.text: I've been here several times and will continue to go because of there Pinakbet! It's the closest thing I've found to good Filipino cooking here in Arizona! There's other items on the menu that are just as good! Very kid friendly and the staff are helpful. The only problem I have is the prices. I think it's a little pricey for the amount of food you receive.

kH03MxnGsSJ_u-0ys91pFA.text: Almost as good as mom's cooking! Everything was delicious and I loved the little band that was playing while we ate. I would have probably given them 5 stars if they let me sing karaoke...

Rx4b1n6S0nrg6K-RrQm_OA.text: Brought my family here. I'm glad that the staff spoke Tagalog so that my mother could talk with them natively. We ordered a lot of food and it was very good and affordable. We'll be back!

Rwe3M3r4HVJ-KP0I1c42rg.text: I have to say that this Filipino restaurant caught me by surprise. It's one of the better ones that I have been to including the ones out here in Socal. The food just had the right taste, without the added greasiness or the added msg. Not only that, but they didn't skimp out on the meats. The meat was really meat not just innards. That made me happy. The only thing I found awkward was that the rice came portioned to each plate.. and if you wanted more, you had to ask. I don't know of any other restaurant that does that and if you are conscious about your carb intake this would be a good thing for you, but for someone like me, it felt awkward. Overall great restaurant and if I'm in Phoenix, i'll be by to have more tasty food! :) (We had the dinuguan, lechong kawali, kare kare, pancit malabon i think, sisig and crisp pata) yep and all of them good!

YfADanhC_76TARMC-bzCpw.text: I have been here 4 times. I want so desperately to like this place but the food is less than mediocre at best. The shrimp in the pancit smells OLD. I got an eclair from the bake shop and to my horror there were MOLD SPOTS under the eclair on the paper. I will NOT BE RETURNING...EVER.

0WZ-XpVX801dldkEyFVOeQ.text: I've been to a few Filipino restaurants (in a variety of cities) and this by far is one of the best.  The establishment is very clean and the entire set-up (tables, chairs, etc.) allows for a comfortable eating experience. The food is served in reasonable proportions. I ate one of my favorite filipino dishes, Kare Kare, which was cooked to near perfection. I recommend this dish to anyone that eats over here. Our group also ordered Crispy pata, which offered the right texture and crunchiness that one expects from a dish. The service was also fantastic. I highly recommend this place!

FxjDj4h_ItyGeg-O2vz71Q.text: I've been here about 3-4 times since it first opened. At first the quality and portion servings were good,but the price is not well worth it with the small portions of food they serve you now.  Last time I was at Casa, I ordered Kare Kare, it was like 7-8 bucks and it only had 3 pieces of meat in it. Sames goes for the Menudo. I ate with three people, we ordered Menudo, Kare Kare, Pancit and two other items that I can't remember plus three Pepsi sodas. The whole bill came up to almost 85 bucks!!! I've been to other Filipino restaurants in Phoenix and spend 35 bucks for 4 people and had better experience in portions, servings and quality.  To add to this, the kare kare meat tasted odd, it was chewy and didn't taste fresh. I tried to give this place a couple of tries,but just can't enjoy it.   The only thing I love about this place is the Lecheon Kawali and the sinigang was acceptable. Not to mention the Sago Gulaman was really good.  Some of the dessert cakes are ok as well. The Yema was awful, did not taste anything like how I taste it in other Pinoy restaurants in Vegas, California and even home made ones I tried from family, friends etc.  You'll have to be a fan of this place to really enjoy the food. Its a very family oriented restaurant, service was really good and a friendly environment. They just have to improve on serving portions and quality of taste and they will be good.

j5lde5E-yPk5g4_rDDyCWg.text: I love the food here. I was born and raised in Manila so I have been homesick for Pinoy food. Everything at this place is baked or cooked on premises from scratch. I had the lechon kawali and it was crispy good. I have tried the dinuguan ("pork chocolate stew") with rice and puto -- deelish! My American fiance loves the Pancit Bihon Guisado. We both love the macapuno tart and the special halo-halo. This is a rare sit-down Filipino restaurant with friendly servers. The rest room is clean, complete with amenities like hair spray. We are on our way there today for our nth visit and don't mind having to drive from North Scottsdale. We stop by Fry's Electronics while we're there as it is nearby and we kill 2 birds with one stone. Malinamnam!

nwHG6SRlp8upZmUhu5d2fg.text: Came here on a saturday night with a filipino friend.  The place has a small filipino bakery with decent varieties of goodies.  We ordered sisig, pork sinegang, dinuguan.  It was good! on saturday night, this place will have a line dance and on friday night, they will have a filipino live band music playing in the restaurant.  It was fun and definitely will go back!

pkBIzCXAFDIAgG_15LL-qA.text: I love this place. There seems to be more food available than is on the menu. I've had the Pancit Bichon, Chicken Adobo and Lumpia and they're all excellent! I'm a regular!

h8jIK2sNPUCnAyU5XpBv2A.text: Fellow Yelper Kurdy S and I were curious about this Pin@y bakery, so we met here for lunch during one weekend. Looking from right to left, the interior was divided into a bakery section followed by a sizable dining area. The vertical glass case carried an assortment of colorful Pin@y sweets, rolls, and desserts. Everything looked extremely tempting. The atmosphere was casual, down to earth, and unassuming.  The Chicken Adobo ($7.99) came with bone-in chicken, vinegar, soy sauce, and garlic. The chicken was tender and meaty, but the marinade could be deepened by the soy sauce and more striking with the mix of sharp flavors. For some reason, the expected flavors were flat and notes to plateau and climax were severely missing.  The Sisig ($7.99) encompassed diced pork and pork ears sauteed with garlic, onions, lemon juice, and fresh chopped jalapenos. Given all the sharp tasting ingredients, the flavors should have been far more robust, striking, and complicated. To the chef's credit, the positives were the food did not appear greasy; and the textures came out firm and not overcooked. The side of pancit was lacking flavor, and unfortunately, equally unimpressive. I've had all of these items homemade, so the experience was modest at best given this being one of the only two Pin@y bakeries in the area.  Ube Hopia ($4.99) was my least favorite item from the bakery. The exterior was noticeably staled without the fresh flaky textures. Although the purple ube filling was delicious, the air pocket inside was too big for me to recommend it. To this day, my favorite Pin@y bakery is still Valerio's.  Despite the limitations, the Sago't Gulaman ($2.50) was truly outstanding. It came in a big glass of tapioca, gelatin, and crushed ice. The drink was impressively refreshing to counteract against the hot summer weather. Of all the things I've tried so far, this is one item that I'd highly recommend.  Service was friendly and kind, but the food did take some time to arrive at our table. I still believe their food is a good gateway for those experiencing Pin@y cuisine for the first time. However, their targeted audiences could be much more inclusive of those who have already been introduced to the cuisine. I'd be interested in trying the other Filipin@ restaurant in the area before deciding whether to return.

EMlN83VbORxWriiLaaVYmw.text: Great Filipino food in the valley! Comfort food for every Filipino. I bring my foreign friends here too when they say they want to try Filipino food and it never fails! Definitely recommended!!!

Y0gG8_MBVxm946oOF67lzg.text: My BF and I enjoyed our lunch from this place; we ordered the chicken inasal and the sisig. Both entrees had rich flavor especially the chicken inasal, the meat just came off the bone so tenderly. Miss Tess was very kind and made a few adjustment to our halo halo although it cost a couple dollars more, but the Ube was worth it. We would definitely go back here again. Salamat po, nabusog Kami ng tama.

Q_fXPS__XeZIYhyYVQSjlA.text: This is a great Filipino restaurant if you're ever in the mood to try. The service is phenomenal and super friendly. Everything is great and they come in pretty nice portions. I come here all the time with my girlfriend. Definitely recommend!

Qfkh2-87SfSM8U5UZTXVng.text: If this review was for the dessert only it would get a 4/5 stars but unfortunately my whole family and I were not satisfied with any of our entrees. Rice and noodles were DRY, lumpia smelled like it was spoiled, and the pusit looked like it came straight out of the can, and everything was overpriced. I'll come back for the baked goods but definitely not the sit-down restaurant.

PKnoERGe0ZmtiWDfMPJreg.text: Well first impressions hot wish they had the air up more. Server was friendly. Ordered the lumpia and chicken adobo. Has a real mom and pop feel. But the focus is on the food not trying to be more then a hole in the wall restaurant and bakery. Tv was playing the Filipino station go figure. Appetizer came out quickly. Best part was it tasted the most authentic lumpia that I have tasted in the valley.  Main coarse came out chicken adobo with rice and noodles. Now I choose this because 1 this is one of my favorite dishes to make my self and reminds me of growing up. If I had a last meal it would be chicken adobo. How did this compare... Close real close and to be fair to compare what you make at home is a little unfair because you know exactly how you like it. What was great it was full pieces of chicken bone in not cafeteria how many pieces can you make a chicken leg. Rice is rice so it was good. But the real surprise was the noodles. They tasted great. Chicken tender and flavorful just not like mine.   I enjoyed the food so much I want to bring my grandfather and see what he says. And maybe it can remind him of home.

-hb0ujIuRKFIKcIsnn4GuQ.text: Great food!! Great service!! Our dinner was romantic with the live soft music we will be sure to go back and I also enjoyed their Halo-halo Filipino dessert!

orzUICBaRvnagMgqeT2YCw.text: As you enter you pass a small baked goods shop and enter a banquet hall like dining room. I'm not real familiar with Filipino food and asked our waiter what spices are used in the Chicken Inasal. He said, "I don't know but it's a good choice." I order it anyway and then our waiter starts SINGING KARAOKE. Starting with "Love is a many splendid thing" followed by many Frank Sinatra tunes. He sings well and it is kinda neat but a little weird.  Someone runs my husband's plate out. I wait at least ten minutes and then someone runs my plate out. Both meals had a very home style quality to them. Both had falling apart tender meat that was infused with flavors. The Beef Kalderetta tasted like a beef stew that anyone's grandmother would make but with two french fries instead of potatoes. The Chicken Inasal was a whole chicken leg on the bone that was marinated and grilled and served with a vinegar-soy kind of sauce for dipping.  The baked goods look inviting to us and I read on the Phoenix New Times that these baked goods are among the Best in the Phoenix Area so I wanted to try some.  We ordered the mango and ube (purple yam) tarts to try. A waitress brings them and I notice a big crack on the purple tart and it looks very dry. We try to eat them but neither of us can PENETRATE the tarts with a fork because they are very hard. My husband breaks them open with his hands and they are hard like rocks and are inedible. We bring this to the attention of the waitress and she says the manager will talk to us. He brings out one new purple tart and says nothing is wrong with his tarts and they just needed to be warmed up. I think to myself well then who is suppose to warm them up? Am I suppose to bring my own personal oven with me when I go out to eat? The new tart he brought over was good unlike the first tarts. Our hard mango tart just stayed on the table. We get the bill then pay and leave. The manager runs after us and says that we didn't have to pay for the desserts. That sort of rubbed us the wrong way because nobody took the desserts off the bill and nobody told us we didn't have to pay for them.  If you come here you need to be a telepathic to know what they don't tell you and you need to bing your own personal oven if your desserts are served hard.  You might want to give this place a try but I certainly can't recommend getting dessert.

7LYllEE5v3NjZA6Svxp97w.text: Great Filipino food, owners and staff provided excellent customer service! I had the Crispy Pata, the Panceit, and the Sioux Pow....all great!

c7r5p93nLvI5dbrP5FH-zw.text: We have a lot of Filipino restaurants in Las Vegas, but this is by far a better bakery than I've been to. The staff is polite, and the restaurant is clean. The portions are decent and flavors are on point. I have never had ube cheesecake and yum! Only downgrade of star is that the chicken adobo was a little more bland than in used to and the sauce was thicker than I am used to.

ZBNp7cmuvj1V0lvIDSWJJg.text: This is always my go-to place when the need for Filipino Food rises.  I make it a habit to stop here when I'm within a few miles of the area.  Love the Food, the lumpia, kare-kare, lechon kawali, pancit malabon, spaghetti and others - lots of authentic Filipino food to choose from.     I've been to a few Filipino restaurants in Phoenix, some of them have come and gone, but by far, Casa Filipina has been consistent.   I also feel that this is by far the Cleanest Filipino restaurant i have seen here in the Valley.   We all know how some of them are.  I'm not overly critical about the less salt, less garlic or less stuff -  being a restaurant located in the U.S. - you have to learn to adopt, most American's won't eat food with too much salt, or too much garlic or too much of things.    That's what the table salt is for.  I grew up in the Philippines for 20 years, and have lived in the U.S. for 20 years - i don't like too much shrimp on my food, nor do I want to eat anything too salty or with too much garlic. Casa makes their food in the perfect balance of just making it "right."   Even my non-filipino wife eats the food here.  I brought a few non-filipino friends to this place and they all love the food.

DotipAywofNymFHmaPxwYQ.text: A friend told me about this location and I decided to try it. In my opinion, it wasn't all he made it out to be. I had the pork (Carnitas style), but the meat was dry. The sauce in the dish had good flavor, too bad the meat was just too dry to eat. My main issue with this place was the service. We were seated for about 15 minutes before anyone came to get our drink order and it's a small restaurant. Once we (table of 3) ordered our food, all our dishes came out at different times...up to ten minutes apart from each other. You had to eat before everyone got their food or your food would get cold.Food is ok, but the service was dismal. The service is the reason for such a low review.

z_DHfSjYDeA8EJmzRF-usA.text: I always enjoy eating at this place even if you waitress, at this visit, was a bit forgetful to our request.  The owners are very nice and do all the cooking and baking.  I will always come back here to get my Filipino food fix. Thank you Casa Filipina.

xtA3qK2oKW-Y3LZsxOfmDA.text: Great food and very warm hospitality. The Kare-Kare was great and the pastries were awesome. Try the Macapuno Tart! Definitely would recommend if you are in the Phoenix area.

85o9y8QqYngnb0LUAuiOQQ.text: Been here twice... Been disappointed twice... So this deserves twice the star.  Sorry 'kababayan' ! I hope you can take this constructive feedback to become a better representation of our food.   I can proudly say that I know Filipino food. I think I have some credentials. Being a Filipino and growing-up in Philippines surrounded by good and authentic Filipino food should give me enough basis for my feedback and critic.  Let's start with the good. Place was clean and it did not have the oily and fishy smell of a usual Asian restaurant. Service was good. We were greeted as soon as we walked in. Food was also served quick and at the right temperature. The Halo-halo had a good balance of sweetness and creaminess. The Leche Flan on top of the Halo-halo had the firm and velvety like consistency that is common to a Filipino Leche Flan. The sweet Taro at the bottom gave the dessert a genuine Filipino flavor. Even the shaved ice is a positive. It is really easy to ruin a Halo-halo with brick like sizes of ice. The Sago't Gulaman was also really good. I got ahint of vanilla on every sweet sip and the jello had its own characterand flavor. The Tapioca balls was made the star of the drink with just the right bite but had the softness common to  a tapioca back home in the Philippines.   Now the bad. It breaks my heart that I am criticizing a Filipino restaurant but I love Filipino food so much, I just want to make sure it is represented well.  I would have wanted some water. I believe water should still be served even if our order had Halo-Halo and Sago't Gulaman. We also got a little bit of a funky smell on our Pancit Malabon (common to improperly stored rice noodles/sauce). Knowing what a really freshly cooked Pancit Malabon smells like, I just know that the sauce or the noodles on my order may have not been handled properly. Since I have already mentioned the Pancit Malabon, I might as well finish my review of the could have been noodle delight. The pancit flavor was very very very flat. It was very far from the layers of salty, sweet, garlicky, seafood umami flavor. I was saddened by the lack of seafood (got maybe 3-4 smal shrimps). The crunch from the pork rind was none existent. I was also looking for the smoked fish saltiness that makes Pancit Malabon a pancit from Malabon.   I have tried their adobo and caldereta on my last visit. Both fell very short on flavor and character. A little more salt and pepper and maybe a lot more garlic might make difference.   I've tried their Crispy Pata as well. Which I think was AWESOME!   There are some goods, but I've had more bads during my previous visits. I just wish Filipino food can be represented a little better. I wish the layers of flavors and texture present in each bite of a Pinoy dish comes out the next time I visit the restaurant I have been trying to love.

termZnUkvYU4EA_IgSsIlQ.text: The food was so good and tasted homemade. The service was great and it's clean. They specialize in Filipino baked goods, and it's all made from scratch. My favorite was the ube cheesecake and ube croissant. Get those two if you like taro or ube. Amazing.

NdGmVr5IUmwdh5iW_fujaQ.text: I arrive in Phoenix and the first thing i look for is Pinoy Food and i found this Casa Pilipina Bakeshop and restaurant .. the food was good and very friendly staff as they welcome you as soon as you walk in ..too bad i came in on the weekdays.. it seems to be theres a live band going on every weekend (love live band) ..next time!!!

1fI2ndFuvJyBy_Jan43O2Q.text: A buddy invited me to this place..... Our first time.............. The Fresh Lumpia is just so bland that you just gotta drown it out with lumpia garlic sauce........  I think the prices here are so ridiculously over-priced. Just ain't worth it.  If only the food tasted good....... Just ain;t good enough......  Stay Away       ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Stay Away....................... Stay Away

hy7qx4zfxy65fFA7G_QzsA.text: Food:  - Lumpia: 10 pieces of yummy Filipino pork egg rolls.  4/5  - Pancit Bihon: clear, thin noodles stir-fried with carrots, cabbage, and chicken topped with green onions. Tasted good but I wish there was more to it. It was basically all noodles with very little vegetables and chicken. More veggies would have been great. I didn't care for more chicken because it was dry. The dish came with a side of bread. It had the consistency of a moist cornbread. 3/5  - Chicken Adobo: 3 pieces of boned-in chicken with marinated with garlic, soy sauce, and vinegar. Served with white rice. The chicken was flavorful and tender. 4/5  Service: The waitress was friendly and polite. One of the ladies from the back, I'm not sure if she was the owner or the chef, came out to greet us and asked how our food was. She thanked us for coming and wished to see us back again. I thought that was really nice of her.  5/5  Final thoughts: Authentic Filipino food. I would love to come back and try their bakery.

I7GiWxOURe1THycCfROzJw.text: Been here a few times. Nice, friendly people.  Last week, we ordered:  * Lechon Kawali: good; loved that it was super-crispy! * Filipino Bistek: ummm... tasted like Beef Stew, with gravy and all - not the oily-soy-saucy thing that you'd normally see with Bistek * Lumping Shanghai: a little bland, but not too bad * Garlic Rice: s'okay * Halo-Halo: delicious, sweet enough, and had lots of ingredients * Sago't Gulaman: yum!  Took home the following: * Cassava cake: pretty good * Bibingka: so bland (and I was particularly looking forward to this). I had to sprinkle sugar on it to make it taste better. * Yema: they mixed langka in it; not bad * Tiramisu cup: Eeek! This is not what Tiramisu tastes like! Son and I each had a bite and threw it away. * Chocolate Mousse: same as the Tiramisu, we ended up throwing this away after one bite.  We'll most likely come back, since there aren't a lot of Filipino places around.

Zlwaa3w_HnRwK_3GBp6cDg.text: I delivered for this place once and after waiting 10 minutes for order to get done they did not even bother to provide all the food for the customer. I don't open bags when delivering, just ask the restaurant if all food is in the bag. When I delivered to customer they told me it was missing half the order. I called the restaurant on my way back and they said they did not scroll all the way down to see all of order. When I got there he said oh let me go back and get it. Another wait while they finished preparing the rest of the order. There were maybe 4 customers in the whole place. I noticed that some flan syrup had spilled in the bag I brought back to ensure the customer got their complete order this time and I had asked him if he could please clean up the bag so it would not be that way when I delivered it again to the customer. He said oh the bag must have been tipped to the side when delivering it. I assured him it was not tipped over by me in the ride in the car or when handing it to the customer, but maybe by the customer when she began looking at the contents in the bag. He acted as if it was a problem cleaning up the bag. He even had the nerve to remind me not to tip it while delivering it by showing me how to carry it. I Know I never tipped it in the first place as the customer handled the bag while checking over the order. The problem lays in the fact they did not ensure they provided the customers entire paid order in the first place. I had to make 2 trips to provide the customer their order. Delivery drivers should not open the bags to check the contents as that is the restaurants job. Restaurants want to stay open then they need to make sure they have great food and great customer service. I will never deliver for this place again as they have horrible customer service.

I0m9xyA2Q8YZYszMr8b-Qg.text: $9-$13 a plate ... Pretty good food.  I usually eat out to Filipino Restos in San Diego but wanted to give this one a try since we were in the area.  Baked goods were good so far.. Cheese roll was different but good. Wish they had more family style eating. Served for individual plates only.

DWil5ClIp4VlotNlk_XKhA.text: So i'm married to a Filipina and have the privilege of traveling to the Philippines every year in Cebu. When I am in the Philippines I know what the native food there is like first hand. When I went to Casa Filipina and ordered Bistek Tagalog and my wife had ordered Sisig, the food is not "Americanized" but very authentic.   Filipino food isn't necessarily for everyone's taste pallet, but if you try the food there, it is very delicious and cooked/flavored to perfection.

nEKrmk_iOczjCSQOIpK7cg.text: I've only lived in AZ a little over a year. Coming from San Diego, one of the things I miss most is my Filipino food. I wasn't surprised that the Filipino restaurants were scarce here. So when I had the opportunity to go to one, I did my research to figure out which one I wanted to try. I am so happy that I choose Casa Filipina because it was absolutely DELICIOUS!   I consider myself a foodie. Went to culinary school and did my stint in this industry. So needless to say...I'm a little picky. I knew I wanted to try their lumpia shanghai because my son's birthday was the following day. I was trying to determine whether or not I was going to make my own for the party or order through them. Thankfully they were incredible! It brought me so much comfort eating them. PLUS, when I ordered 100 of them for my son's 5th birthday party the next day, they were a HIT! No one at the party had ever had lumpia before. And I think it made a pretty good impression that they would never forget it.  The other thing I ordered was Pancit Bihon. Just the day before, my husband and I were discussing how we have never had a really good pancit bihon back in San Diego--unless, of course, it was home made. My first bite of this and I was in heaven! Finally a flavorful pancit bihon that, one bite of, I stopped and texted my husband, my sister and my mom-in-law, on how amazingly delicious it was! I plan to order the pancit and the bihon for my other son's 1st birthday in just a few weeks.  The third thing I ordered was the Bistek. Now I have to preface my thoughts on this dish with how my family members are incredible cooks. I grew up on Bistek and my sister bangs this out of the park. So when I first saw how thick the sauce was, more like a gravy, it intrigued me. I'm used to a thinner sauce. I didn't let that dissuade me. After I took a bite, my first thought was how tender the meat was...tender like butter practically. Then when I got to analyzing the flavor, it wasn't the distinct soy sauce and pungent lemon tang I'm used to. It was good, but I guess I just preferred my sister's approach to it more.   I had to end my meal with Halo-Halo because it's my fave--I intentionally ordered as much as I did, so that I had some to take home to the hubby for dinner. The Halo-Halo did not disappoint. My only feedback would be for it to be in a bigger cup because mine was SO full of goodness, that I couldn't stir everything together. Tony, the owner, was even sweet enough to come out and ask me if it had been my first time eating Halo-Halo because I wasn't mixing everything together. Which is the perfect segway to the service...  I didn't realize how much I was missing the interaction with my culture. As soon as I was greeted in tagalog, my heart was happy and I think I had the biggest smile on my face. My server was super sweet and attentive. Tess even came out and served my check. Thanked me for coming in. But it was Tony who went out of his way to make sure I was truly experiencing a Halo-Halo, the way it should be. He even offered to stir it all up for me. After I told him that this wasn't my first rodeo, I explained how the cup was just too full.   I can't wait to return and bring my entire family!!!

hrsZPGEx-SlClxodFgX9Nw.text: Super friendly! Lumpia looks,smells & taste delicious! HIGHLY RECOMMEND. Price great because of the quality of food that you get.

5-P7ntiR_obFCKxkRR-9fA.text: I ordered their 6 inch ube cake, and it was great! It was slightly drier than I would have liked, but the ube flavor stood out which was the most important thing for me.  For those who haven't had ube before, the best way I can describe it is a sweet potato/taro flavor.  They used a whipped cream based icing, so the cake was light and wasn't toothachingly sweet like your typical American cakes too.  I recommend ordering the cake a few days in advance, as it looks much more vibrant than the one on display.  Overall, this place is a solid bakery that I would order cake from again!

photos.caption: Photo of Casa Filipina Bakeshop & Restaurant - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Ube cake - Call in a few days ahead to have one freshly made so that you get more vibrant colors! Also, sorry it looks a bit messy...

Ui-qMw_S97PvILxeuBSPcQ.text: Adorable. Warm. And inviting. Me, my niece and my brother were greeted upon entering with warm smiling faces. I knew we would be taken care of!  The food was great, simple but not simple on flavor. They wait on you practically hand and foot. There was an electric keyboard in the corner of the room, and behind it was an older quiet gentleman playing Over The Rainbow and a few others everyone would know. It was peaceful. I can see why this place is visited so frequently.   A man approached my niece and asked her name. She immediately became the shy flower she is and closed up and began getting upset. We responded for her, and he offered a song just for her.  Well, you can imagine what happened. Poor little lady started crying. But no worries, it was a very sweet gesture. And Ill always remember it.   Of course my niece forgot her trauma as soon as she caught a glimpse of the bakery shelves. Oh dear. She picked out her prize, a chocolate mousse tower. An even exchange for her tears, right?   She devoured it within moments and was incredibly happy.   If you haven't been here yet. You must. They treat you like family.

pOKfkfL1mrlfh_iIiPQ-1A.text: So, after reading all the great reviews about this place I was really excited to check it out. In the interest of full disclosure, I am a Filipino who grew up in the Philippines and migrated to this great country when I was 24. I love Filipino food and would go out of my way to get some. With that out of the way, I was really disappointed with this restaurant. I was hoping to love it and find a regular place to eat at. My family and I checked it out over the weekend in search of a Pinoy place to order our Christmas eve meal from. Sad to say, this did not fit the bill. We ordered the pancit malabon, pork barbecue skewers, and an array of desserts. None of them were up to par.

XHBBKPfiPE8M_UUHQkxvBQ.text: Kare kare = to die for Karaoke = deadly   Performers were having fun but I wasn't able to enjoy my food while trying to ignore the music

JJlhp4v46UHDSnOFTarbbg.text: I have been wanting to try this place out for a few months now, so finally last Friday my mom & I decided to come here for lunch.   When you walk in your eyes are immediately drawn to all the goodies in the bakery case. But we were here for lunch so we brought our attention back to that. We were seated in the dining room that was pretty empty, there were only 3 other parties. After scanning the menu we ordered the following to share: lumpia (crunchy pork eggrolls), pancit (rice noodles w/veggies & chicken that came w/puto-a sweet rice bread) & ginatang sitao kalabasa (string beans, squash & shrimp sauteed in coconut milk w/rice). The lumpia was amazing, so yummy! The pancit was delicious as well, great flavor. The veggie dish was my least favorite, however my mom loved it. Oh I also did not care for the puto.   After we finished lunch we looked at all the treats again & decided to order some to go. I can't recall what my mom got but I got the following: cannoli, flan, cheese roll & siopao (steamed bbq bun). The cannoli was for my hubby & he enjoyed it. The flan was yummy but had a much thicker consistency than I am used to. I did not care for the cheese roll at all, I think if the cream cheese had some sugar added to it it would be much better. I had the siopao for lunch today & it was pretty good.   After chatting with the owners (very sweet, husband & wife) we found out they offer line dancing every Saturday for $8. My mom loves to dance & is going to check it out this Saturday with a couple girlfriends. If she has fun I might even join her next time!

v4dzAm19yoGHF7cRJ7s8-A.text: The fiance and I were on a mission to surround ourselves with some comforts from home since we were unable to be home with our families in Cali on Easter. We decided to find a Filipino restaurant and see if it could compare to our mom's famous cooking (nothing ever does though, right?)  We had the choice between Casa Filipina and Halo Halo Kitchen which are only a few blocks apart. For no known reason we decided to go with CF if only for the fact that it was closest to us at the time. This is not in our home area so it's unfamiliar territory for us but we ventured on until we found it in a run of the mill shopping plaza with a Big Lots (a nice bonus since it was actually open on Easter so we got to do some after lunch browsing).  We didn't know what to expect from CF but we know we weren't disappointed. The small bakery opens up into a pretty good sized restaurant with a good amount of tables. There were several other parties there including what looked like an after church Easter family gathering of about 12. Good sign #1.  We were greeted warmly and seated right away. We were surprised at the menu choices and excited about the options they had. Of course, there are some Filipino dishes we wished they had but hey, you can't have everything. What they did have was pretty darn good.  We ordered the sisig [see-sig] (sauteed bits of pork with onions) and the pancit malabon [pon-sit muh-law-bone] (noodles with sauce, hard boiled eggs, shrimp and cruched chicharon, or pork rind chips, on top). I also got sago to drink (sweet syrupy drink with tapoica pearls and sweet rice jelly) b/c it made me think fondly of family parties when my dad would always make a punch bowl of the stuff.   The food was flavorful and offered good portion sizes. It came with a hefty scoop of white rice, naturally. The entrees also come with a piece of sweet rice bread called puto - i know, i know, not the best name for those of you who speak Spanish but that's what it's called, really! Random factoid: I learned this little double meaning when I got in trouble in 3rd grade for bringing puto to my class for the multicultural pot luck. Much explaining was done at that time too so I figured I'd include it here. Just an FYI.  One thing to note is that the food will take a little while to come out so be prepared. The server warned us in advance and was very apologetic about the wait but I have to say this....every Filipino restaurant I have been to that has heat lamps and premade food has been wrong on so many levels. Legit Filipino food is not quick to make and not good when you make it in large batches and just have it sit there waiting for someone to order it. So, just be patient and know that it's worth the wait.   Since we are constantly trying new places we will surely be trying other Filipino joints in the area but we will also be going back to CF for some good food to make us feel at home.

NsreJ7MqGqaSoXwZXB_G9Q.text: Heard about this restaurant from a friend and I was amaze by the food and their friendly service. I tried the chicken adobo and it was amazing! The chicken came apart with no effort and it had a great honey glazed taste. The portions were a good amount for their low prices. I couldn't  get enough of their amazing dessert!

3PM1B03DNcVIBySrtFF7xQ.text: This is definitely my favorite place to get delicious, authentic Filipino food. Their dishes are best enjoyed with an open mind, as you won't see items such as pork chocolate blood soup on your average restaurant menu. I've been here several times and the owner, who seats you herself is very nice and friendly. My favorite dish here is the Lechon Kawali which is a deep fried pork belly dish served with a liver sauce. Their desserts are also amazing, my personal favorites are the Halo-Halo and pretty purple ube mousse tarts. They also have live music on the weekends which is also so fun to hear a Filipino-style crooner. The delicious, authentic food and wonderful ambiance will keep you coming back to this restaurant again and again.

HGaqnY6AJDNCVPGK1-WRwQ.text: The food here is really good, but the customer service is horrible. There is only one older gentleman there who is remotely friendly, but the older lady and heavy-set guy always has an attitude problem and are very slow in helping their customers. You really have to ask them to do their job and even then, they still drag their feet.

6kphaAaG11-twl3wuEmgBA.text: The food was delicious and the ladies and gentlemen working there were so sweet. The food made me miss home and "mahalang". Thank you Casa Filipina for a wonderful dinner.

mKZGlZq0sBZRr5o-rX5siw.text: This has the best authentic Filipino restaurant for the Phoenix area. I don't think I've found anything that can compare. The diniguan(excuse my spelling) was awesome! But I am use to a little spicier but for the price it's well worth it.  Also had their flan and jackfruit pastries in the bakery section, those seemed to be freshly made that same day. They had a huge selection in both the restaurant and bakery, I would definitely go back!

eVTXjOZEg_HeugaV36Zx4Q.text: Masarap!!  I was craving Filipino food and Casa Filipina had come highly recommended from our Kuya.  Firstly, once we entered, we were promptly greeted by EVERYONE in the bakery! That really set the tone for the rest of our dining experience. Once seated, we ordered Bistek Tagalog, Chicken Adobo, and Lechon Kawali. I really wanted Tosilog, but I knew there was no way I could finish it ha ha ha!  Bistek Tagalog: Delicious! Beef was tender, the gravy was flavorful and thick, and it was topped with 2 potato slices and onions.   Chicken Adobo: this is a common dish and one I always recommend to people who have never tried Filipino food. Here, the adobo was soft and tender. The sauce was savory and gravy like, which is my fav!   Lechon Kawali: very crispy and fatty (in a good way). The liver sauce was soooo good! Did I mention, crispy?   For dessert, we got halo-halo to go and it came with flan on top! Yum! Can't go wrong with halo-halo!   Service: impeccable!! Each waitress was extremely friendly and VERY attentive! Our water was refilled plenty of times and she even brought us more rice when it ran low.  All in all, considering I grew up eating Filipino food, I'd say this was easily one of the best Filipino restaurants I've ever eaten at!! I felt right at home and welcome, like I had gone to a Tita's house and she cooked some bomb Filipino food. Ha ha!! When I'm in town, I will definitely be back!

76-zW-HTuc8hqXpsR5pa2Q.text: This place is somewhat hidden, not known till my brothers decided to check it out . They were so impressed with the quality of food and service that they decided to take the whole family out the following day a total of 9 persons . The food was cooked to order and is very authentic Filipino cuisine. I loved the crispy pata, lechon kawali, pinacbet and beef caldereta. The humongous fresh lumpia was my favorite it was delicious! The service was friendly and awesome as well! I'm from California we're the Filipino restaurants and Turo turo joints are known for great food, I will put Casa Filipino part of that list ..... oh before I forget the baked goods they are delicious.....

s1PIK_ziiro1fJgecuQDhA.text: I had a short interaction at this bakery today. I came in with my two children. The entryway was dark. They had an assortment of baked goods in a glass case. There were two women working at the front. Neither of which greeted me. It was dead, so a bit awkward to have no customer service. Alas, I had two children in tow who wanted sweets. They had tiramisu, chocolate mousse, tarts, and various Filipino goodies that looked beautiful. On the far left side there were three 12 inch cakes. The icing had cracks in it, from obviously sitting there for a period of time. Upon further inspection, one of the baked goods were covered in MOLD in their glass case. I was mortified and high tailed it out of there. I am disappointed that I will not be able to try their baked goods, but they lost a customer and a lot of trust that their food would be safe to eat.

tR8QYhAWeJLn5X3Hk1hNTA.text: Amazing traditional Filipino bake Shop! This was a real hit with my Gf's Filipino family and coworkers back in California and now a request when I go back to Arizona. I wonder if this place could ship? I ship in tamales and other foods from various parts of the country.

75EuGHfOI95PtRTDAE47CQ.text: Food was great, satisfied our craving for a filipino dish in the area, the place is clean although needs a little bit of renovation, server and owners are very friendly

rL64oLlyfP3XXWLfeG81YQ.text: My friend and I are going to school in Arizona and we're missing some authentic Filipino cooking from home. We found Casa Filipina on Yelp and decided to give it a try. We loved it so much that we came back today (we went yesterday also). The owners are very welcoming and inviting. We were seated quickly and our orders were taken as soon as we were ready. We both got meals that come with pancit and rice. My friend got the bangus which came with a dipping sauce, tomato, and cucumber. I got the sinagang na baboy and lechon kawali. The food came out really quick considering the bangus needed to be fried. My friend said her fish was cooked beautifully and evenly (because some places don't cook it evenly.) The sinagang na baboy has very good flavor, the meat was very tender, and the vegetables were nice and fresh. The lechon kawali was nice and crisp on the outside and juicy on the inside. Today when we went my friend loved the bangus so much that she got it again. I got the kare kare and, like the sinagang, the meat was so tender. They gave so much meat in the portions also!  Onto the bakery part: we got ube cheesecakes that were amazing. I also got the casava, but have not tried it yet. All of their pastries and baked goods look very scrumptious and I hope to try everything in their pastry case and menu in the future when I come again.  TL;DR - Come here if you're craving some authentic Filipino food.

IJ87zIPq9QC_Ndi4AQkzPQ.text: Oh yes, the Filipino Gods finally answered my prayer! I was looking for a delicious, fresh, non-buffet, authentic Filipino restaurant and here it is ladies and gentlemen. Filipino restaurants in the Phoenix area are slim so most of the time, you just have to go with what you got regardless of quality and taste.   I came to visit and even though the decor needed some updating and the a/c was out, the food made up for it. We ordered Shanghai lumpia, chicken adobo, and pancit malabon. Every bite was masarap (delicious)!! I was so freaken happy that I also got halo halo, pan de sal, and ube pastries to go. What was also great was the price - for everything I ordered and with tip, I paid $50. We left with leftovers and yummy bakery goods so I really think it was worth it! The employees (owners) were also so sweet and they hope I will come again.   I will definitely come back and I invite all of you reading this right now to come and try it out! You won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Casa Filipina Bakeshop & Restaurant - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pancit Malabon and Chicken Adobo
Photo of Casa Filipina Bakeshop & Restaurant - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shanghai lumpia

N40Vkj7b-2_9pJEfMfHAKA.text: Casa Filipina opens at 9am for breakfast and lunch - yay!  We did not want to wait until noon for lunch as we had a craving for a non-traditional brunch, meaning without eggs or bread, but with rice and pancit.  Filipino food, for non-Asians or non-Filipinos, is a derivation of other Asian foods, you get rice, noodles, tasty stews of pork, beef, or chicken.  Also Roast Pork!  In this case, Roast Pork Belly because not many establishments have a facility or enough requests to roast an entire pig daily.  But, oh well, Roast Pork Belly will do!  Our family is ethnic Chinese but similar to other Asians or Pacific Islanders, we'll eat anything.   So for breakfast, we had Kara Kare (curry pork with eggplant), Chicken Adobo (they serve a toned down version, they give you a side of amped-up shrimp paste which you can add to the adobo), and Lechon Kawali (Roast Pork Belly with a liver based sweet dipping sauce).  Each dish comes with rice and pancit.  Too much food for the three of us, so our son boxed it up for dinner.  The place is also a bakery - we ordered Ube Cheese Rolls and regular Cheese Rolls to go.  The rolls were good and flaky with the right amount of filling.  Tess, the owner, said the rolls were just out of the oven.  She is so nice and helpful!  We told her we were driving back to NorCal after moving our son into school and she offered assistance to check on him - so nice.  Island hospitality!  Will be back in October to visit!

photos.caption: Photo of Casa Filipina Bakeshop & Restaurant - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Kare Kare, Chicken Adobo, and Lechon.

rfGj6w4ukBUszQollN91vg.text: It's hard for me to eat at a Filipino restaurant because I always compare the dishes with my mom's home cooking. But this time I was impressed by the pancit malabon (noodle dish with orange colored sauce) and the letchon kawali (roast pork). The pancit tasted right, not too salty and the sauce garnished was the right amount on the noodles. And the letchon was not greasy, it has a crunchy top texture and soft on the meat part.   The service is good and I'll  be back again to try other dishes. This restaurant it was a treat for me because I only eat Filipino food occasionally.

In addition they have a bakery area with some tasty pastries. I cannot rave more about this place and I'm very much a fan. I highly recommend to anyone to try them out you won't be disappointed.   I look forward to our next visit.  Support your local business owners!

They had live music while we ate and the waitress was very helpful!   *Pardon my spelling on the food We ordered lumpiang shanghai to start and it was phenomenal! We have family friends that used to cook it at home all the time and the flavors were exactly the same!   Next up we shared pancit (another must-have!), an eggplant dish and chicken insali. rIgODXFP8pQcsN4wc7-0RA.text: The food was okay. I would call this more of a fast service food place than a bakeshop. My family and I tried it for the first time and we live about an hour away. When we ordered our food, it took awhile then when it was received, it was cold. I love filipino food but honestly you could make everything they do at home in shorter time. At the time I went, they did not have that many desserts or "bakery" items.

g34_o-ghHRPTnQiXtkklzw.text: This review is for the bakery only!  Fresh off my yearly trek to Manila, I was craving a taste of home. And what does home taste like? Ube and leche flan, apparantly.  Cue Casa Filipina Bakeshop and Restaurant.  I ran in at 1pm on a Saturday and ordered a halo-halo special, plus ube halaya roll and an ube cheese tart. The halo-halo took about 5-8 minutes to prepare. No worries, because I moseyed over to the dining area so I could watch TFC on the TV.  The halo-halo special was DELISH. The leche flan was such a nice touch. And they didn't go ham on the jellies. Honestly, I typically hate halo-halo because the jelly ratio is always TOO DAMN HIGH. This one, however, was just right.  I stored my ube baked goods in the fridge to be consumed later that evening.  The ube cheese tart was divine. I would definitely repurchase - I love the cheesy taste combined with the ube. The ube halaya roll was decent - I would have liked a little bit more ube, but still good. I love the ube crumbs on top too.  If I didn't live so far away.. I would come more often just so I could have a little taste of home. (And to bring home some ube treats too.)

Pe7Vnb9cleVwzlNOMVXviw.text: Friendly people but the small Ube cake was dry and so was the pastry. Hesitate to purchase from the bakery again.

0wyvxS0RsFIg2NICGrONpg.text: This place is a rip off. I called ahead of time to pick up some food for lunch. I was really craving some lechon kawali so I figured that I'd give this place a try. I ordered just that. My total just for the lechon kawali alone was $13! 1lb of pork belly at the market is less than $3/lb & from what I ordered, it only weighted out to be like half a pound of pork.   When I got to the place to pick up my order, I had to wait at least 15 more minutes for it to be done. Their excuse was that there were many orders placed before mine. there was no more than 8 people dining in at the time. Keep in mind that when I arrived to pick up my food, I had places an order 20 mins before. Finally, when my order was ready I went up to the counter to pay. & the person who rung me up just kept staring at me. It made me very very very uncomfortable.   The Lechon Kawali overall was not the best. Very bland. The sauce that it came with didn't even make it any better. It did have that perfect crunch I was looking for though.

wPPg9V9brEO6I-ZNYuKkyg.text: This is a great option to experience the unique, exotic flavors of the Philippines.  Our party of five ordered several things from the menu, including Shanghai lumpia, pancit bihon, crispy pork lechon, pinakbet beef calderata, and of course chicken adobo, and we shared all family style.  The dishes were prepared and presented nicely, coming from the kitchen over a short period of time.  The serving sizes are a bit lean given the pricing, but nonetheless we were all happily satiated at the end of dinner.  The host/servers did not hover, but were readily available and responsive when we needed something.  It was a very friendly and relaxing atmosphere.  While we did not order anything from the bakery on this trip, I have previously stopped by the bakery to buy Filipino treats.  The taste of cassava, ube, coconut, mango, and various other exotic flavors proliferate the large selection of desserts.  The Filipino sweet breads are hard to find in Phoenix, but they are here at your fingertips.  Overall, it is a FILIPI-YES to this Filipino restaurant.

jWe0U_bEOAMrAGCFoS07RA.text: Decided to give this place a try.  Party of 3, one ordered the Shanghai Lumpia, barbeque pork skewers and I ordered the pancit malabon.  Order took awhile, my companions were almost done with their meal. My order of pancit malabon arrives, I give it a taste and smell and it tasted and smelled a bit funny. Took 2 more bites and decided that I wasn't going to eat it.  I informed the waitstaff that it smelled and tasted spoiled.  They offered to replace it with a to -go ordered. Went against it. Didn't want to take my chances of getting sick.

EnBtgxzabJ339x7c2GX5cQ.text: God forbid you shop around.   My sister-in-law called to see how much the sisig was by the platter and the guy asked her name as if we were going to place an order. My SIL said she didn't want to place an order without knowing how much the price was. Then the guy says, "what are you just shopping around?" And then HANGS UP on her!   Honestly - it's our fault for even considering this place. The food doesn't even look good. Plus who wants to support people who are rude to fellow Filipinos.

dYFjwViCQ8G0r0UXRkHy4g.text: Tony and Tess,                                                                                                                    Thank you so much for being able to accommodate our requests for the amount of food that we ordered for our recent holiday party!  Great food and deserts.                   My favorites dinner choices are the beef steak, panzit, and of course the appetizing egg rolls!  For desert, I always choose the panocha!                                                       We were truly impressed that you were able to pull this off  with what  I would consider "short notice"                                                                                                                                    . I  happily and proudly recommend Casa Filipina for as much as a simple desert, to an evening dinner, or for an elaborate holiday party! You won't be disappointed. Thank you again Tony and Tess, and to your staff.                                                    Sincerely, Paul Tillwach

H0fGF5KCutQZr9ltbqJ-8Q.text: the food is kind of pricy for what its worth

lBxEiM499wj4S6sDSDiYmg.text: I grew up in San Francisco and lived most recently in Jersey City - both had an abundant list of Filipino restaurants and grocery options to choose from, so I am a fish out of water here  - knowing there are only a total count of 6 Filipino restaurants in the entire Phoenix metro area!    Thank goodness for Casa Filipina!  It's a 25 mins drive from OT Scottsdale, but at least it's a decent go-to for home cooked Filipino food.  Super simple resto - but clean.  We had a couple of the chicken dishes, the beef steak and squid.  Overall the food was tasty and service decent.  My tip:  if you have big appetites, order extra.    Because it is such a trek for us, I also ordered food to go for "baon", fried tilapia, pancit malabon (Filipino style egg noodles) and tortang talong (omelette with eggplant and pork).  Equally enjoyed these dishes at home!  Of the 6 Filipino restaurants I've come to learn about so far, I recommend this restaurant for Filipinos and folks who have yet to try Filipino food alike. We will definitely return when in need for a fix

nkHaLGp4uDLLBlKRxmrF-A.text: Moving here in 2012, I took some time to search online for various restaurants in my area. When Casa popped up, it was exciting because of my own Filipino heritage.   The food is great. You can see the focus and care they take with their menu, as each item is well made. Filipino food is some of the most flavorful you can find, and Casa makes some of the best.

3BygtOJJM8tRYATyWZ3bLA.text: Seriously the best Halo Halo I have ever tried! I literally crave it hahah Do yourself a favor and get one when you visit. So far I have gotten the tosilog which was really good, juicy and delicious marinade, the garlic rice was great and they include some sort of I guess vinegar sauce which is great with it all. I have also tried the chicken inasal, which was super juicy and had great flavoring. The portions are great. While there I met the owners who where super friendly. They have a lot of sweets too which I haven't tried any yet but def will be with time. I know the flan is amazing since they put that in the halo halo, seriously some of the best flan I have had too. Highly recommend going here!

1hMkeHG5LavOrcpFjfRvpQ.text: Another dinner here at Casa.  We were here just 2 weeks ago.  My wife wanted the fried Vermicelli (we call it fried Bee Hoon) and they serve it on every dish.  We had completely different dishes, the Pork BBQ on Skewers is just tender, they managed to keep it moist inside, it's sweet and savory at the same time.  I went for the Chicken Inasal which a special spice blend, Tess, one of the owners came by chatting with us, she said it's has a blend of lemon grass on it.  The skin is so crispy, the spices caramelize into the meat gives this umami taste.  Don't leave without having some of their bake products.  Definitely try the Ube (Purple Yam) Cheese Cake.

SV1TYb6xr68VEfG_nVZHIA.text: Came here with our our of town visitors from Arizona and was a bit let down to be honest.   It was empty when we came in around 5 pm but they greeted us with the biggest smile on their face. Customer service was great which is why Im giving it a solid 3.   The food was okay. Coming from Virginia and being filipino myself My expectations were a bit high, too high because I just dont think Ive ever been to a filipino restaurant I didnt like. We ordered pancit, bistek, lumpia and sinigang. The portion was okay. More than most but a bit pricey from what Im used to with the same portion.  What disappointed me was their bakeshop. We ordered 4 ube mousse cake and we were so excited to get home to dig in and almost choked from the dryness of the cake. It really didn't taste like ube at all and I was a bit embarrassed since I brought my friends here specifically for the cake and it was a bust! We also drove 40 min to get here JUST FOR THE UBE CAKE. We also got the ube cheesecake and that was ok but wheres the dang ube flavor! So disappointed! Im so glad we didnt pay for the $44 6" ube cake they had.   So in conclusion:  Customer service: 4 Food: 3 Dessert

I got the bbq pork skewers which was very flavorful, for me it was a little too much seasoning I could've done less salty. My bf got the tilapia which was perfect!! I loved how crispy and fresh the tilapia was. Finally we both got the halo halo special and it was very yummy! Very clean place, cute local restaurant and friendly staff! Would come back again!

6AKCSmw3c__yKJaRD0ByRA.text: When I travel, I always look for a Filipino resto just like this one that serve authentic Filipino dishes. This was the closest to me at the time. Hubs and I had to wait an hour bcs they were opening late according to their kind note that was posted on the window.   Hubs and I were the very first customers. We ordered several favorites.  The one that stood out the most is the sinigang.  It was simply made with basic veggies but was tasty enough to say "yum". The rest are forgettable.  The lechon kawali was very dry and overcooked in my opinion.     We also ordered the kare-kare and it was just okay because they didn't cook or make their own fried shrimp paste.  Kare-kare is sort of like some mild type of curry which, has the peanut butter base that should have a Really pretty orange-ee color to it. What really makes this dish special is to make your own fried shrimp paste that gives this dish the deliciousness that will present your originality and will make it more memorable to customers.   This is how I also remember my trips- where I had one of my favorite dish and where it took place. This goes for the other types of dining or eating I do on my own or with my love ones.  Anyway, on a good note, the perk was that we were given a lot of steam rice and pancit with our dishes.  You can google pancit if you are not familiar.   Service was very pleasant, it's well-maintained and very clean if you ask me.  That is also important and people remember as well.  Otherwise, I think they do have a favorite dish that might stand out for others. Who knows!? Prices on the menu? Well they vary...

uni5CpsVNLZTygs0M5bp1w.text: This is top-notch cooking and baking, Filipino or otherwise. They have outstanding savory dishes for everyone whether you're picky or adventurous. I highly recommend the lumpia, the lechon kawali, and dinuguan. If you're unsure about what to order, just ask Tess. She was so friendly and introduced us to the menu; that kind of personal touch was greatly appreciated.   P.S. save room for their desserts! They have so many different kinds, and everything I tried was delicious. Don't sleep on them.  P.P.S. I've been reading some negative reviews about the tarts from customers complaining they can't cut through the tart. Apparently they didn't have the common sense to pick the tarts up and bite into them. Do not skip the tarts. Our coconut tart was my favorite dessert of the three we ordered!!!

pmC0dPGkpq84GW0BDrbUKw.text: Wow! Everything was super delicious! Our waitress Rita was super adorable. Very happy and giggly! For our appetizer we had the egg rolls. Perfect crispness. Sweet and sour sauce to dip. My son, who is picky, had the honey chicken which he loved! I had the grilled chicken (don't remember the Filipino names) and it was really. My daughter had something that resembled beef stew. The meat was super tender and delicious. This place was a hit! As far as dessert, we are leaving with s fruit tart, leche flan and a jackfruit tart! Omg! Can't wait to taste! The staff all came to our table to thank us for coming. So pleasant! Definitely coming back!
